title: How Innovative Grafting Technique can change the agriculture forever.

tasks.task: Learn about and understand the new grafting technique for monocot plants.
subtasks: Listen to the scientist explaining the process of grafting.
Comprehend the concept of grafting, which involves attaching the root of one plant to the shoot of another.
Grasp that the rootstock (root) is from one plant, and the scion (shoot) is from another, resulting in a single, healthy plant.
Recognize that the new technique was developed by Julian Hibbard and his team at the University of Cambridge.
Realize the technique works by transplanting unique tissue from plant seeds onto two plants of the same species.
Understand the importance of connecting the roots and stem for efficient food and water sharing.
Note the success of the method on various monocot plants, including bananas, pineapples, onions, and tequila agave.
Acknowledge the potential application of grafting Cavendish bananas onto healthy rootstocks to prevent Panama disease.

tasks.task: Appreciate the benefits of the new grafting technique in agriculture.
subtasks: Consider how grafting can address uniformity issues in banana cultivation.
Recognize the ability to protect banana plants (specifically Cavendish) from diseases like Panama disease.
Understand the broader implications of this technique for other monocots and sustainable agriculture practices.
Visualize the application of grafting for strengthening wheat and oat plants by breeding them with more resistant counterparts.
